summary: This is an email from July 3, 2008, between federal prosecutors discussing the Jeffrey Epstein case. It reveals a victims' lawyer's concerns about the plea deal, Epstein's status in custody, and contradictions about his educational background and work release eligibility.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Copied on the email discussing the Epstein case and the plea deal. He was the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida at the time.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the email. He is in custody, described as being at the stockade, not jail, and is eligible for work release. His educational background (only a high school diploma) is discussed.

persons.name: Goldberger
persons.context: Has met with Epstein in custody along with a psychiatrist. Mentioned as part of the legal team threatening to sue if Epstein receives unfavorable treatment.

persons.name: Ken Starr
persons.context: Referenced as part of the legal crew (along with Goldberger) that will sue if Epstein receives less favorable treatment in custody.

connections.description: Goldberger has met with Epstein in custody and is part of his legal defense team.
Referenced together as part of the legal crew representing or threatening legal action on behalf of Epstein.
Ken Starr is referenced as part of the legal team that would sue on Epstein's behalf.

events.title: Prosecutor Email on Epstein Deal
events.description: A federal prosecutor emails colleagues about a conversation with a victims' lawyer who expressed concerns about the plea deal and revealed information about Epstein's custody status.

events.title: Epstein in Custody at Stockade
events.description: Epstein is reported to be held at the stockade, not the main jail, and is eligible for work release, contradicting earlier information given to agents.

events.title: Meeting on Epstein's Jail Conditions
events.description: Goldberger and a psychiatrist met with Epstein and warned that his legal team (including Ken Starr) would sue if he received less favorable treatment than others.

keyFacts: A victims' lawyer, a former Broward County ASA representing three victims, contacted prosecutors expressing concern about the plea deal and stated his clients could name many more victims.
The prosecutor indicated the office was bound by the deal with Epstein, assuming Epstein completed his performance.
Epstein was held at a 'stockade,' not the main jail, and was eligible for work releaseâ€”contradicting what officials told agents months earlier.
Epstein's defense team (Goldberger and a psychiatrist) met with him and threatened a lawsuit (involving Ken Starr) if he received unfavorable treatment.
The email reveals Epstein falsely claimed higher education (a master's degree) but in reality only had a high school diploma, making him ineligible to teach GED classes as he had offered.
